sen.j: 松井興長（まついおきなが、天正10年（1582年） - 寛文元年（1661年））は、安土桃山時代、江戸時代の人物。
sen.e: Okinaga MATSUI (1582 - 1661) was a person in the Azuchi-Momoyama period and the Edo period.
Okinaga MATSUI (1582 - 1661) was a person who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period and the Edo period.
Okinaga MATSUI (1582 - 1661) was a person who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period and the Edo period.

sen.j: 細川幽斎以来の細川氏家臣。
sen.e: He was a retainer of the Hosokawa clan since the era of Yusai HOSOKAWA.
He was a retainer of the Hosokawa clan since the era of Yusai HOSOKAWA.
He was a retainer of the Hosokawa clan since the era of Yusai HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 熊本八代の初代城主（正式には八代城代。）
sen.e: He was the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Kumamoto (Officially Chamberlain at Yatsushiro-jo Castle.)
He was the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Kumamoto (Officially Chamberlain at Yatsushiro-jo Castle.)
He was the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Kumamoto (Officially Chamberlain at Yatsushiro-jo Castle.)

sen.j: （それまでは忠興が隠居場として八代城を使用）。
sen.e: Before that, Tadaoki used the Yatsushiro-jo Castle as a place for his retirement).
(Before that, Tadaoki lived the Yatsushiro-jo Castle after his retirement).
(Before that, Tadaoki lived the Yatsushiro-jo Castle after his retirement).

sen.j: 父は松井康之。
sen.e: His father was Yasuyuki MATSUI.
His father was Yasuyuki MATSUI.
His father was Yasuyuki MATSUI.

sen.j: 正室は細川忠興娘の古保（こほ）。
sen.e: His Seishitsu (legal wife) was Koho, a daughter of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA.
His Seishitsu (legal wife) was Koho, a daughter of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA.
His Seishitsu (legal wife) was Koho, a daughter of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 式部大輔・佐渡守。
sen.e: He was Shikibu no taifu, Sado no kami (the governor of Sado Province).
He was Shikibu no taifu, Sado no kami (the governor of Sado Province).
He was Shikibu no taifu, Sado no kami (the governor of Sado Province).

sen.j: 出自
sen.e: Place of origin
Place of origin
Place of origin

sen.j: 松井氏は室町幕府の足利将軍家に仕える家で京都に住んでいた。
sen.e: The Matsui clan served Ashikaga Shogun Family of the Muromachi Bakufu and lived in Kyoto.
The Matsui clan had served Ashikaga Shogun Family of the Muromachi Bakufu and lived in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 表現、スペースを修正しました
sen.e: The Matsui clan had served Ashikaga Shogun Family of the Muromachi Bakufu and lived in Kyoto.

sen.j: 将軍足利義輝が永禄の変（永禄8年・1565年）で殺害されると、松井康之は同じく足利将軍家に仕えていた細川幽斎と行動を共にするようになり、その後家臣となった。
sen.e: After Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), Yasuyuki MATSUI came to do things together with Yusai HOSOKAWA and later Yasuyuki became a retainer of Yusai.
Since Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), Yasuyuki MATSUI had been with Yusai HOSOKAWA, and later Yasuyuki became a retainer of Yusai.
sen.cmt: 表現、文法を修正しました
sen.e: Since Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), Yasuyuki MATSUI had been with Yusai HOSOKAWA, and later Yasuyuki became a retainer of Yusai.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)に細川家は丹後国の領主となり、家老の康之は丹後国松倉城を任せられた。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the Hosokawa family became the feudal lord of Tango Province and Yasuyuki, Karo (chief retainer) was assigned to keep the Matsukura-jo Castle in Tango Province.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the Hosokawa family became the feudal lord of Tango Province, and Karo (chief retainer) Yasuyuki was assigned to keep the Matsukura-jo Castle in Tango Province.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the Hosokawa family became the feudal lord of Tango Province, and Karo (chief retainer) Yasuyuki was assigned to keep the Matsukura-jo Castle in Tango Province.

sen.j: 松井一族の働きぶりをみた豊臣秀吉は康之を石見国半国18万石の大名にとりたてると申し出たが、康之はこのまま細川家に仕えることを希望し辞退した。
sen.e: Although Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI who recognized the way the Matsui family worked made an offer to select Yasuyuki to be a Daimyo (feudal lord) of a half of Iwami Province with 180,000 Goku crop yields, Yasuyuki excused himself from accepting the offer due to his wish to continue to serve the Hosokawa family.

Although Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who recognized the way the Matsui family worked, made an offer Yasuyuki a position of Daimyo (feudal lord) of a half of Iwami Province with 180,000 Goku crop yields, Yasuyuki declined the offer due to his wish to continue to serve the Hosokawa family.

Although Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who recognized the way the Matsui family worked, made an offer Yasuyuki a position of Daimyo (feudal lord) of a half of Iwami Province with 180,000 Goku crop yields, Yasuyuki declined the offer due to his wish to continue to serve the Hosokawa family.

sen.j: しかし事件が起こった。
sen.e: However, an incident happened.
However, an incident happened.
However, an incident happened.

sen.j: 細川氏が豊臣秀吉から関白豊臣秀次の謀反連座の疑いをかけられたのである。
sen.e: The Hosokawa clan came under suspicion by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI of being involved in a rebellion of Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI.
The Hosokawa clan was suspected by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI of being involved in a rebellion of Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI.
sen.cmt: 表現、スペースを修正しました
sen.e: The Hosokawa clan was suspected by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI of being involved in a rebellion of Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 秀次からの借銀の返済や、秀次縁者に嫁していた忠興の娘御長（おちょう）差出要求に対して松井康之が奔走し、ことなきを得た。
sen.e: Relative to demands for payment of a debt to Hidetsugu and for proffering a daughter of Tadaoki, Ocho who married a relative of Hidetsugu, Yasuyuki MATSUI was busily involved in the matter and the situation didn't become serious.

Relative to demands for payment of a debt to Hidetsugu and for proffering a daughter of Tadaoki, Ocho who married a relative of Hidetsugu, Yasuyuki MATSUI was busily involved in the matter and the situation didn't become serious.

Owing to Yasuyuki MATSUI's hard work with regard to demands for the repayment of a debt owed to Hidetsugu and in acting as a matchmaker in seeking a husband for a daughter of Tadaoki (who was married to a relative of Hidetsugu) called Ocho, the situation didn't become serious, though.

sen.j: 興長はこの康之の次男である。
sen.e: Okinaga was the second son of this Yasuyuki.
Okinaga was the second son of this Yasuyuki.
Okinaga was the second son of this Yasuyuki.

sen.j: これに感謝して、細川忠興は娘こほ（11歳）を興長の妻とした。
sen.e: As a token of his gratitude, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA made his daughter Koho (11 years old) Okinaga's wife.
As a token of his gratitude, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA made his daughter Koho (11 years old) Okinaga's wife.
As a token of his gratitude, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA made his daughter Koho (11 years old) marry Okinaga.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦いでは、細川家は、関ヶ原、丹後田辺城、豊後杵築城と三方面で戦闘したが、興長は忠興に従って会津征伐、関ヶ原の戦いへ赴いた。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, the Hosokawa family took part in battles in three regions of Sekigahara, Tango Tanabe-jo Castle and Bungo Kitsuki-jo Castle, but Okinaga, following Tadaoki, went on an expedition against Aizu and to the Sekigahara battle field.

In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, the Hosokawa family took part in battles in three regions of Sekigahara, Tango Tanabe-jo Castle and Bungo Kitsuki-jo Castle, but Okinaga, following Tadaoki, went on an expedition against Aizu and to the Sekigahara battle field.

In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, the Hosokawa family took part in battles in three regions of Sekigahara, Tango Tanabe-jo Castle and Bungo Kitsuki-jo Castle, but Okinaga, following Tadaoki, went on an expedition against Aizu and to the Sekigahara battle field.

sen.j: なお、興長は岐阜城攻めで負傷したため、関ヶ原での合戦には参戦していない。
sen.e: Due to his injury in an attack on Gifu-jo Castle, he did not take part in the Sekigahara battle.
Due to his injury in an attack on Gifu-jo Castle, he did not take part in the Sekigahara battle.
Due to his injury in an attack on Gifu-jo Castle, he did not take part in the Sekigahara battle.

sen.j: 戦後、細川忠興は豊前国・豊後国（現在の福岡県と大分県の一部）39万石余りの大名となったが、戦後、松井康之は豊後国木付（杵築）城を任せられて2万5千石という大名格の領地が与えられた。
sen.e: While Tadaoki HOSOKAWA became a Daimyo (feudal lord) of Buzen Province and Bungo Province (present Fukuoka Prefecture and part of Oita Prefecture) with over 390,000 Goku crop yields after the war, Yasuyuki MATSUI was assigned to keep the Kitsuki (Kitsuki)-jo Castle in Bungo Province and given a Daimyo-class territory of Five thousands Goku crop yields.

While Tadaoki HOSOKAWA became a Daimyo (feudal lord) of Buzen Province and Bungo Province (present Fukuoka Prefecture and part of Oita Prefecture) with over 390,000 Goku crop yields after the war, Yasuyuki MATSUI was assigned to keep the Kitsuki (Kitsuki)-jo Castle in Bungo Province and given a Daimyo-class territory of Five thousands Goku crop yields.

While Tadaoki HOSOKAWA became a Daimyo (feudal lord) of Buzen Province and Bungo Province (present Fukuoka Prefecture and part of Oita Prefecture) with over 390,000 Goku crop yields after the war, Yasuyuki MATSUI was assigned to keep the Kitsuki (Kitsuki)-jo Castle in Bungo Province and given a Daimyo-class territory of Five thousands Goku crop yields.

sen.j: 松井興長の経歴
sen.e: Career of Okinaga MATSUI
Career of Okinaga MATSUI
Career of Okinaga MATSUI

sen.j: 松井佐渡こと松井興長は天正10年（1582年）に丹後国久美浜で康之の二男として生まれた。
sen.e: Sado MATSUI, or Okinaga MATSUI was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki in Kumihama, Tango Province.
Sado MATSUI, or Okinaga MATSUI was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki in Kumihama, Tango Province.
Sado MATSUI, or Okinaga MATSUI was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki in Kumihama, Tango Province.

sen.j: 兄松井興之が朝鮮出兵で戦死したため松井家の世子となり、慶長16年（1611年）、父・康之が隠居したのに伴い松井家の家督を相続した。
sen.e: As his elder brother, Okiyuki was killed in battle in the Japan's Invasion of Korea, he became the heir of the MATSUI family and succeeded to the Matsui family property in 1611 when his father, Yasuyuki went into retirement.

As his elder brother, Okiyuki was killed in battle in the Japan's Invasion of Korea, he became the heir of the MATSUI family and succeeded to the Matsui family property in 1611 when his father, Yasuyuki went into retirement.

As his elder brother, Okiyuki was killed in battle in the Japan's Invasion of Korea, he became the heir of the MATSUI family and succeeded to the Matsui family property in 1611 when his father, Yasuyuki went into retirement.

sen.j: 1600年関ヶ原当時に細川家世子であった細川忠隆からの松井興長（新太良）あての自筆書状5通が松井文庫に現存している。
sen.e: Five autograph letters of Tadataka HOSOKAWA who was the heir of the Hosokawa family at the time of the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600 addressed to Okinaga MATSUI (Shintaro) are existing at Matsui Bunko library.
sen.cmt: 「新太良」の読みは、用語集、サイトでも見当たらず、とりあえず訳しましたが、定かではありません。
sen.e: Five autograph letters of Tadataka HOSOKAWA, who was the heir of the Hosokawa family at the time of the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, addressed to Okinaga MATSUI (Shintaro) exist in Matsui Bunko library.

Five autograph letters of Tadataka HOSOKAWA, who was the heir of the Hosokawa family at the time of the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, addressed to Okinaga MATSUI (Shintaro) exist in Matsui Bunko library.

sen.j: 寛永9年（1632年）、細川家が豊前・豊後から肥後国熊本藩に国替になると、興長には玉名郡・合志郡の内に3万石が与えられた。
sen.e: When the Hosokawa family was transferred from the fief of Buzen and Bungo provinces to that of Kumamoto Domain, Higo Province in 1632, Okinaga was given a territory of Thirty thousands Goku crop yields in Tamana and Koshi counties.

When the Hosokawa family was transferred from the fief of Buzen and Bungo provinces to that of Kumamoto Domain, Higo Province in 1632, Okinaga was given a territory of Thirty thousands Goku crop yields in Tamana and Koshi counties.

When the Hosokawa family was transferred from the fief of Buzen and Bungo provinces to that of Kumamoto Domain, Higo Province in 1632, Okinaga was given a territory of Thirty thousands Goku crop yields in Tamana and Koshi counties.

sen.j: 寛永14年（1637年）に島原の乱が起こると、藩主細川忠利の命により派兵の手配、幕府や他藩との交渉に奔走し、翌年の原城の戦いでは、自ら3,700余りの兵を率いて出陣した。
sen.e: When the Shimabara Rebellion took place in 1637, he was busily engaged in dispatching arrangements of troops and negotiations with Bakufu and other Domains by the order of Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, the lord of the Domain and went into battle leading his own troops of over 3,700 soldiers in the battle of the Hara-jo Castle.

When the Shimabara Rebellion took place in 1637, he was busily engaged in dispatching arrangements of troops and negotiations with Bakufu and other Domains by the order of Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, the lord of the Domain, and went into battle leading his own troops of over 3,700 soldiers in the battle of the Hara-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: スペース、文法を修正しました
sen.e: When the Shimabara Rebellion took place in 1637, he was busily engaged in dispatching arrangements of troops and negotiations with Bakufu and other Domains by the order of Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, the lord of the Domain, and went into battle leading his own troops of over 3,700 soldiers in the battle of the Hara-jo Castle.

sen.j: 正保2年（1645年）に八代城主だった細川忠興（三斎）が亡くなると、正保3年（1646年）から興長が八代城を預かることになった。
sen.e: When Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA who had been the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle died in 1645, Okinaga came to keep the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in 1646.
After Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA who had been the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle died in 1645, Okinaga came to keep the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in 1646.
After Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA who had been the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle died in 1645, Okinaga came to keep the Yatsushiro-jo Castle in 1646.

sen.j: 八代城は一国一城令の例外とされて存続し、代々松井家が八代城主を務めた。
sen.e: The Yatsushiro-jo Castle remained as an exception of Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province) and the MATSUI family kept the Castle for generations as the load.
The Yatsushiro-jo Castle remained as an exception of Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province), and the MATSUI family kept the Castle for generations as the load.
sen.cmt: スペース、文法を修正しました
sen.e: The Yatsushiro-jo Castle remained as an exception of Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province), and the MATSUI family kept the Castle for generations as the load.

sen.j: 興長は、忠興の六男（細川寄之）を養嗣子に迎え、細川別姓である長岡姓を賜り、長岡佐渡守と称した。
sen.e: Okinaga adopted the sixth son of Tadaoki (Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA) as an heir and was given the surname of Nagaoka, another surname of Hosokawa, and assumed the name of Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami.
Okinaga adopted the sixth son of Tadaoki (Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA) as an heir and was given the surname of Nagaoka, another surname of Hosokawa, and assumed the name of Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami.
Okinaga adopted the sixth son of Tadaoki (Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA) as an heir and was given the surname of Nagaoka, another surname of Hosokawa, and assumed the name of Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami.

sen.j: 興長は慶長5年（1600）の19歳での初陣以来80歳で亡くなるまで細川忠興、忠利、細川光尚、細川綱利の4代の主君に仕え、細川氏を支えた。
sen.e: Okinaga supported the Hosokawa Clan having served his lords for four generations, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, Tadatoshi, Mitsunao HOSOKAWA and Tsunatoshi HOSOKAWA since his Uijin (first battle) at the age of 19 in 1600 until his death at the age of 80.

Okinaga supported the Hosokawa Clan having served his lords for four generations, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, Tadatoshi, Mitsunao HOSOKAWA and Tsunatoshi HOSOKAWA since his Uijin (first battle) at the age of 19 in 1600 until his death at the age of 80.

Okinaga supported the Hosokawa Clan by serving four different heads of the clan (Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, Tadatoshi, Mitsunao HOSOKAWA and Tsunatoshi HOSOKAWA) in the years since he first went into battle at the age of 19 in 1600 until his death at the age of 80.

sen.j: 松井家は細川血族として代々筆頭家老を勤め、明治まで続く。
sen.e: The MATSUI family as a blood relative of the Hosokawa family kept the position of the Hitto karo (the head of chief retainers) for generations, which continued until the Meiji period.
Until the Meiji period, the MATSUI family kept the position of the Hitto karo (the head of chief retainers) for generations as a blood relative of the Hosokawa family.
Until the Meiji period, the MATSUI family kept the position of the Hitto karo (the head of chief retainers) for generations as a blood relative of the Hosokawa family.

sen.j: 松井家は細川家臣でありながら、実質上の肥後八代支藩3万石の大名格藩主であったともいえる。
sen.e: While the Matsui family was a retainer of Hosokawa family, it may be said that it was substantially a Daimyo-class branch-domain lord of the Yatsushiro branch Domain of Thirty thousands Goku crop yields in Higo Province.

While the Matsui family was a retainer of Hosokawa family, it may be said that it was substantially a Daimyo-class branch-domain lord of the Yatsushiro branch Domain of Thirty thousands Goku crop yields in Higo Province.

The head of the Matsui family can be described as being essentially a daimyo-class lord of the Yatsushiro branch domain who had a stipend of 30,000 koku in Higo Province during his time as a retainer to the Hosokawa family.
sen.cmt: 一部変更しました。Thirty thousands Goku→30,000 koku

sen.j: 熊本県八代市の八代市立博物館や松井文庫には、第二次世界大戦の空襲を免れた多くの松井家歴代の史料が残されており、研究が進められている。
sen.e: At the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and the Matsui Bunko library in Yatsushiro City, Kumamoto Prefecture, there are many of historical materials of the Matsui family for generations which survived the air raid in the World War II, on which studies have been carried on.

At the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and the Matsui Bunko library in Yatsushiro City, Kumamoto Prefecture, there are many of historical materials of the Matsui family for generations, which survived the air raid in the World War II, and the work is proceeding with these materials
sen.cmt: 表現、文法を修正しました
sen.e: At the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and the Matsui Bunko library in Yatsushiro City, Kumamoto Prefecture, there are many of historical materials of the Matsui family for generations, which survived the air raid in the World War II, and the work is proceeding with these materials
